review_blob: Pours opaque black, with a thick film of fine, dark brown head on top. Tons of chocolate aroma in the nose, with bits of coffee and dark fruit. Alcohol is quite noticeable. Dark chocolate and roasted malts dominate the complex flavor of this one; coffee and dark fruit once again make appearances, along with vanilla and a light smokiness. Fortunately the alcohol that showed up in the aroma is well hidden here. Thick, rich, and smooth, with very little carbonation.

Pours a hazy dark reddish brown, a bit of light passes through. 1/2 finger head dissipates quickly. Smell is of dark fruit, roasted malts, whiskey, oak, vanilla. Roasted malt is pretty prominent in the taste, with a bit of dark fruit. Nice whiskey and oak tones once again; nothing too overpowering, all are simply nice touches that enable a full enjoyment of the other flavors. Light-medium body with light-moderate carbonation, a bit syrupy but mostly pretty smooth. Quite dry for a porter.
beer_name: Elevator Horny Goat Barrel Aged Porter

review_blob: Pours a clear, very dark crimson/brown. 1/2 finger foamy tan head with great retention and lacing. Chocolate actually stands out in the smell most prominently; caramel and dark fruits add to the malt flavors. Resiny hops slightly detectable. Sweet dark fruit dominates the flavor; raisins, caramel, prunes, and molasses quite noticeable as well. Not much direct hop flavor, but a subtle balancing bitterness which stops things from getting anywhere near cloying. Thick and syrupy, with light but prickly carbonation.

Pours a clear copper-amber color; two fingers of fine white head with decent retention; not much lacing. Smells of toasted malts, and amazingly like bread; definitely picking up more of a bread/toast flavor than with any other beer Ive had. Light caramel malt aroma; no hop presence here. Taste again starts off with bread, with a bit more of that caramel malt. A bit of floral hops on the finish, which provide balance to the beers lightly sweet flavors. Thin-medium body, moderate carbonation, very smooth.

Pours a hazy golden-amber color; two finger head with great retention and beautiful lacing, all the way down the glass. Traditional IPA smell: some citrus and pine hops alongside some caramel and biscuity malts. Slightly yeasty notes, and a floral aroma comes out with warmth. As far as taste, malt flavors stand out here more than those of the hops, but hop bitterness is stronger than malt sweetness (much to my enjoyment). Flavors include caramel, toffee, biscuits; grapefruit, more grapefruit, and spruce. Moderate body/carbonation; mostly smooth, with a dry finish.

Pours a cloudy light reddish amber, with one finger frothy white head. Decent lacing. Smell is of orange, grapefruit, pineapple, and yeast; a little bit musty. Tastes of bubblegum, citrus fruits, and a little bit of caramel maltiness. Light body, moderate carbonation, with a dry finish.

Pours dark, dark brown/black with one finger of foamy dark brown head, which subsides slowly to form chocolate milk lacing all around the glass. Aroma contains lots of coffee, as one might expect, alongside dark chocolate and roasted malts. Very pleasant taste, sweet "quality" coffee flavor with more balancing dark chocolate. Roasted malts provide a solid backbone. Prickly carbonation, smooth and milky.

Pours a dark cloudy reddish brown, with two fingers head- viewed from the top, my glass looks like a bowl of oatmeal. Smell is mostly of dark fruit, slightly tart; some molasses and nutty smells. Taste is of mild nutty/fruity sweetness, with little bits of citrus. Neither are particularly complex, and the finish is mostly watery. Thin-bodied, with very light carbonation.

Pours dark black/brown/red just slightly less dark than most imperial stouts, so that light can get through. One finger foamy tan head, good retention. Dark fruit is dominant in the aroma, alongside coffee and charred malts. Taste follows on this, adding a bittersweet chocolate finish. Medium body (light for an imperial stout); moderate carbonation. Slightly too sweet to be wholly enjoyable, but good nonetheless, and worth a try.
beer_name: Ballast Point Sea Monster Imperial Stout

review_blob: Pours a slightly hazy golden amber, one finger of quickly-dissipating head. Smells of fresh banana, coriander, orange peel, flowers, Belgian yeast. But, things go downhill from there... taste, at first, is spicy and peppery; fruity sweet with complimenting toffee and caramel malts. Unfortunately as the beer begins to warm an enormous alcohol flavor comes out, masking and overpowering the rest of the flavors. Thin-medium body, moderate carbonation, smooth; not an enjoyable drink as the other flavors can in no way stand up to the alcohol.

Pours a cloudy golden amber; 2 fingers frothy white head. Smell is of light caramel malts, fruity citrus hops, and the distinct smell of butter. In the taste, caramel malts again, not much hop flavor... a metallic flavor has replaced the unfortunate buttery smell. Light body, light carbonation, rather watery.

Pours a clear, dark, reddish brown. One finger foamy off-white head, decent lacing. Smell is very malty roasted malts, caramel, brown sugar. These flavors come through very strongly in the taste, though their sweetness is balanced by hop bitterness. Medium-bodied, very smooth, moderate carbonation.

Pours very dark brown/black, one finger foamy tan head. Aroma is of chocolate milk, coffee, and light roasted malts. Chocolate also stands out in taste more bittersweet here. Chocolate milk on the finish; coffee and roasted malts still hanging around. Medium+ body, smooth and creamy, moderate carbonation.

Pours a cloudy reddish-amber, almost no head. Aroma is of grapefruit and pineapple hops; caramel and biscuity malts. Taste follows on each of these, with hops and malts complimenting each other to build a very sweet taste, which Im not particularly fond of. Very nice on the palate however; medium-thick body, moderate carbonation, creamy.
beer_name: Tyranena BGW Hop Whore Imperial India Pale Ale

review_blob: Pours stout black, with < 1/2 finger fine, tan head. Spruce and grapefruit hops dominate the smell, although the malt backbone still holds its own; lots of cocoa and roasted coffee beans. Taste is similar to a black IPA at first, more like an imperial stout as it warms. Hop bitterness again is quite evident, with a good deal of roasted malts too. Nice bittersweet, dark chocolate finish. Medium bodied, moderate carbonation (thinner body and more carbonation than most imperial stouts). Slightly sticky mouthfeel.

Pours pitch black, with a thin, dark brown head on top. Aroma is of chocolate, roasted malts, marshmallows, wood, and smoke. Taste starts off with charred and roasted malts; caramel and chocolate follow, as do light vanilla tones as the beer warms. Moderate bitterness provides balance. Medium-thick body; very creamy and sticky. Light carbonation.

Pours a clear, dark, cola red; good finger of fine off-white head. Smell is of sweet biscuity malts; not much variety, but enjoyable nonetheless. Taste is of sweet, caramel malts with a hint of black licorice. Somewhat watery and simple; not a big fan. Thin bodied with moderate carbonation, and a slightly syrupy/sticky mouthfeel.

Pours a pale yellow with two fingers of frothy white head. Smell is not very appealing skunky, with an indistinguishable sweet malt smell. Taste is a large improvement over smell; sweet cereal grains; light grassy, peppery, floral hops. The combination packs much more flavor than I expected from this beer given the light appearance and palate (speaking of which, its very light, with prickly carbonation and a dry finish). Possibly a bit too sweet for my tastes, but nonetheless enjoyable and unique. Seems like a great beer to have chilled on a humid day.

Pours very dark red, with one finger off-white head. Aroma is of sweet malts toffee, caramel, biscuits, dark fruit, chocolate. Taste brings out the dark fruits even further; very sweet, with a bit of balance from spruce/grapefruit hops. Thin mouthfeel, moderate carbonation; velvety, creamy texture.

Wild Blue is not only an absolutely vile beer; it may be one of the most disgusting beverages to ever cross my lips. First of all, Im dubious about its claim of being a "beer;" from first sip, all this beer comes across as is a good amount of cheap blueberry cocktail juice (think the 99 cent per half gallon high fructose corn syrup garbage they sell at dollar stores/serve at elementary school parties, and youre there) with a bit of cheap malt liquor (or diluted vodka) added. No malt or hop flavors or scents are detectable, only a cloying, overpowering amount of sugar and artificial berry to hide the 8% ABV, presumably from drinkers who would be intimidated/awed by the idea of an 8% beer.

Its quite an effort to not give this beer straight 1s; I probably wouldnt choose it over the worst of light beers or 40s if given the option, but Ill leave it with a generous 0.7 in hopes (?) that there is a worse beer out there. Wild Blue, thats the best I can do for you.

Pours a foggy caramel brown; lots of large suspended yeast sediment even after decanting. Aroma is earthy, funky, spicy, herbal, and fruity. Taste is tart and complex theres something new with every sip. Builds on elements of smell; lots of caramel, Belgian yeast, and herbs ginger and cinnamon stand out. Medium bodied and moderate carbonation. Quite enjoyable and quite unique when compared to all other beers Ive sampled; pick this up if you get a chance/you have a good chunk of spare cash.

Pours a pale, hazy, golden yellow with minimal white head. Aroma is powerful and complex; herbs, led by rosemary dominate alongside floral hops, Belgian yeast, black pepper, biscuity malts. Taste follows up on the herbal punch, introducing grassy and citrus hops which add just a bit of tanginess to the flavor. Light malt sweetness and moderate yeast flavors as well. Thin, crisp, and smooth.
beer_name: Victory / Stone / Dogfish Head Saison du BUFF

review_blob: Pours a yellow-golden color with one finger of white head. Smell is earthy, grassy, floral; a bit of light citrus hops and sweet malts. Taste, unfortunately, cant quite back this up its rather weak and simple, tasting mostly like grass and black pepper with few other flavors showing through. Thin mouthfeel, very dry finish.

Pours a hazy amber color; one finger foamy white head, impressive lacing. Smell is sweet and malty, with citrus hops. Taste is of sweet, caramel bready malts balanced well with bitter grapefruit and spruce hops. Medium carbonation, medium body; quite smooth and slightly creamy.

Pours pure black; little head/lacing. Smells of chocolate, coffee, vanilla, oak, bourbon, oatmeal. Chocolate and coffee upfront in the taste; less oak/bourbon than expected, but better than being overwhelming. Suprisingly high amount of alcohol detectable in the flavor for being less than 10% ABV. Thick, creamy, viscous, smooth.
beer_name: Hoppin Frog Barrel Aged BORIS The Crusher

review_blob: Pours a dark brown; thin head which dissipates quickly. Cloudy red when held up to light. Smell is slightly musty; strong roasted malts, bits of sweet caramel, toffee. Taste continues on the sweet/malty themes, a little bit tangy with more caramel and toffee. Medium body; light for style. Slightly stick/syrupy, moderate carbonation.
beer_name: Big Sky Heavy Horse Scotch Ale

review_blob: Pours a hazy, bordering on cloudy amber-orange; one finger foamy white head. Citrus hops stand out in aroma grapefruit and pineapple particularly. Pine, flowers, caramel also detectable. Taste unfortunately cant back this up; overwhelmingly bitter (which I am fine with if it can be backed up) with little distinction of hop flavors; some caramel taste is present but no sweetness to balance. Thin body, moderate carbonation, smooth.

Pours a cloudy, caramel amber color; one finger head and great lacing. Smell is of rich caramel, toffee, cream; less pronounced dark fruit and citrus. Taste is sweet caramel, bready malts dominate; hop bitterness balances nicely. Medium-thick body, moderate carbonation, smooth and creamy.

Pours a hazy light amber color; one finger white head. Smell is most prominently sweet caramel malts; sweet grain, yeast, and light grassy hops back it up. Taste is rich, balanced; sweet malt upfront, balanced by hop aftertaste. Medium-bodied, lively carbonation, creamy and smooth.

Pours stout black, with less than a finger of tan head. Aroma is of roasted malts, coffee, hazelnut, and chocolate. Coffee is at the forefront of taste, along with milk chocolate, more roasted malts, vanilla, oatmeal, and a light bittersweet finish. Medium-thick body, moderate carbonation; both lighter and more carbonated than I expected for the ABV and style, but hey, nothing wrong with that. Highly recommended.
beer_name: Terrapin Wake-n-Bake Coffee Oatmeal Imperial Stout

review_blob: Pours a clear amber, apricot color with more than a finger of foamy white head and a great deal of lacing. Aroma is, as you may have expected, extremely hoppy: floral, piny, citrusy, with a bit of caramel, biscuity malts peeking through. Taste is along the same lines quite sweet with the caramel, citrus, pine interplay. Medium body, moderate carbonation; crisp, with a long, dry finish.

Pours black with a tall, foamy, tan head. Lack of viscosity (in comparison to other stouts) is quite evident as the beer sloshes around quite freely like water. Aroma carries hints of chocolate and coffee, but most predominant is a dark fruit/sugary smell, with touches of smokiness and black licorice. Taste contains many of these elements, but unfortunately an overwhelming cherry presence makes much of them hard to pick up on (not aided by the increased licorice flavor). While I didnt like the taste, I do wish more of my beers could feel like this despite the surprising thinness, Black is extremely creamy, thanks in to a lively carbonation. One glass of this was fine for me tonight; that cherry flavor was just too much (trying not to downvote TOO much based on personal flavor preferences, as its apparent this is a well made beer). Maybe I could find a friend to share the rest of the bomber with...

Pours a slightly hazy peach color, with one finger white head. Smell is very yeasty, funky, with a light fruit sweetness peaches again? Taste is along the same lines lots of yeast, plus a bit of pepper and slightly sweet malts. Smooth, crisp, light body; medium carbonation, and dry finish.

M: smooth, crisp, light body, mid carbonation, dry finis

Pours dark red; steady stream of bubbles flowing throughout when held up to light. Huge frothy, off-white head. Smell is yeasty, funky, tart, and oaky. Taste is similar tart and yeasty are the standouts here. Lively carbonation, thin-medium mouthfeel.

Pours a hazy, light orange amber color, with less than a finger of head that dissipates quickly. Smell has strong citrus hops, a bit of pine; caramel malts and light vanilla/oak tones. Taste is very sweet pineapple from the citrus hops really comes out here, bolstered by the oak. Bitter finish to balance. Medium bodied, medium carbonation, smooth.

Pours dark brown with one finger tan head; reddish-brown when held up to light source. Aroma is very sweet heavy milk chocolate aroma, plus the coconut represented in the beers name. Taste is sweet as well more chocolate, coconut, along with some vanilla and woody flavors. Not much on the hop front, but the representation of sweet flavors is never cloying. Thin body for a porter, moderate carbonation, and creamy.

Pours a hazy golden amber, with one finger frothy off-white head. Aroma is of pineapple, grapefruit, and spruce hops, with a bit of caramel malts. Taste is sweet from the start; caramel malt is more pronounced here, and the pineapple flavor of the citrus hops really stands out. Nice bitter aftertaste from the hops balances things out. Thin, smooth body with average carbonation; not outstanding in anyway, but not lacking anywhere either a very solid beer.
beer_name: Cigar City Jai Alai India Pale Ale

review_blob: Pours your average stout black; no light passing through with a finger of tan head. Smells like chocolate, coffee, and oatmeal after an odd first sniff of house cleaner. Tastes much like smell, with chocolate and roasted malts standing out. Medium+ body, soft carbonation. Goes down easy for a stout but no big desire to have a second.

Pours a mostly clear golden amber with large 3-finger head. Smell is bready and sweet, with pine and citrus hops. All of these come out in taste, in great balance. Light bodied, with moderate carbonation. Very enjoyable and easy-drinking for a DIPA.

Pours a cloudy orange-amber with <1/2 finger head. Smell is hoppy pine and citrus, with caramel and biscuit malts. Taste is the same but kicked up a bit and more enjoyable; very well balanced. Smooth mouthfeel, medium body and carbonation.

Pours cloudy yellow with one finger white head. Smells like sweet grain, corn; light grassy hops and yeast stand out too. Taste is built around that sweet malt, with the hops providing a touch of balance. Slightly metallic aftertaste. Thin body, moderate carbonation, somewhat dry finish.
beer_name: Oskar Blues Mamas Little Yella Pils

review_blob: Pours a hazy golden yellow; one finger white head. Aroma is bursting with citrus hops and a bit of pine; smell drops off a bit following the bold olfactory assault, offering a light grassy, piny hop bitterness to contrast with bready, caramel malts. Light body with moderate carbonation and a dry finish.
beer_name: New Glarus Moon Man No Coast Pale Ale

review_blob: UPDATED: JAN 9, 2011

Pours a dark, hazy reddish brown, with very small off-white head. Smell is extremely malty caramel, toffee, and dark fruit (particularly after warming) prevail. Taste is a creamy, malty sweetness. Dark fruit/raisin flavors bolster the sweetness, making it a bit too sweet for my tastes. Medium body; creamy and smooth; medium carbonation. Wouldnt have another, but a good choice if youre looking for a malt sweetness blast.

Pours cloudy golden, with a small white head. Smell is of piny, citrusy, and grassy hops, alongside a large dose of wheaty aromas. Taste is very hoppy for a wheat ale, strikes a nice and interesting balance with the wheat. Medium body and carbonation; a pleasure to drink.
UPDATED: JAN 9, 2011

Pours a cloudy golden amber, with one finger of off white head which dissipates quickly. Smell is strongly of lime; I pick up a dominant saltiness as well, and a bit of a bready aroma (probably the graham crackers). Taste is extra sour from the lime, almost to the point of being vinegary. A marshmallow finish balances things slightly. Medium body and moderate carbonation. Glad I tried this, just didnt turn out to be my cup of tea (glass of beer).

Pours a cloudy golden color with a tall frothy head. Strong pine and floral hop aroma, a bit of citrus, with caramel malts. Taste reflects smell with just the right amount of bitterness from the hops. Thin body, moderate carbonation.

Pours slightly hazy reddish amber; finger or less of off-white head. Smell is weak, a light, caramel malty sweetness; a bit of breadiness; a small, bitter hop presence. Taste is like a diminished version of the smell, with an unpleasant metallic flavor that gets quite a bit worse as the beer warms. Thin/medium body; moderate carbonation. I appreciate the idea of an organic beer, I really do, but this is simply not a very well done instance of one.
beer_name: Eel River Certified Organic Amber Ale

review_blob: Pours a totally clear golden amber, with a mountainous foamy head and constant stream of bubbles from the bottom of the glass. Smell is wheaty, yeasty, and earthy. A small fraction of the banana smell present in this beers hefeweizen counterpart. Taste builds on this with a light malt sweetness and hop present. Mild bubblegum finish. Mouthfeel is thin and fizzy, very thirst quenching.
